ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Great course! Very interesting!
Professor Geballe and TA Angel Tsu were exceptional teachers. Very knowledgeable and engaging.
The course involved seminars by various speakers.
The guest lecturers, real-world experience
The opportunity to attend COP 17.

Two things: 1) The chance to work with a stakeholder and provide useful inputs for furthering their Durban strategy and general climate change strategies. The list of stakeholders and projects were very interesting; 2) I also enjoyed the chance to bond with classmates through group work, the mock negotiations, attending meetings, etc. This has been one of the best courses at FES Ive taken for getting to know my classmates.
opportunity to listen to various speakers and opportunity to work with external stakeholders such as NRDC, WRI, UNITAR.

I have to say that definitely the best thing about this course was the experience of working with a stakeholder. The second best thing has to be the excellent invited lectures to the class. The third best thing would be the experience of a real life conference.
working with stakeholders on real-world projects.
Minimal funding to attend conferences, working with a relevant stakeholder - gaining real skills.
Everything. Gordon and Angel were a star team to learn from. Angel deserves a lifetime pension after this one.
Working with a stakeholder, where my contributions had a value and purpose was very important.

Was the pairing of stakeholder groups such as NRDC, WRI, Red Cross etc. with student groups to work on specific projects towards COP-17 and Rio +20 intersessional.Students in the class got work with real life issues and NGOs clients. This was well run by both the Prof. Geballe and TA Angel Hsu.

You get the experience and challenge of working with a real client on projects that they are implementing at current conferences. So for my group, we had to quickly learn to navigate the relationships between our client and their partner organizations to obtain information, define expectations, and find a role in which our applied work would be both useful to them while being consistent with our values and goals for the class.The trip to the COP-17 at Durban provided an excellent opportunity to then present our project work (although I was the only one in our group who went) in a professional setting and network with numerous professionals covering the same issues. Going as a confident Yale student with business cards helps in getting almost anybody to talk to you. Definitely provided an unprecedented opportunity to make contacts, discuss controversial ideas we covered in our project with real practitioners, and represent and increase the profile of our school. Websites around the world were linking to our blog posts which offered a unique perspective from Durban. Granted, you have to work to find a niche in this class and there were limited spots to go to Durban, but it's a great way to dive in headfirst to real-world dynamics.
working with real world clients

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Shorter class period, fewer student presentations

I think a lot more upfront education needs to be done about the meeting that the course is focusing on, and this could take place during the time reserved for student presentations. The presentations were horrible. They were far too frequent. There often was not much progress to report between presentations, and doing them so frequently meant everyone put less effort into them; the quality was much lower to the point where they wasted everyones time. 99% of the class checked their email on their laptops and ignored the presentations. This time could have been used to educate us more about the process instead of forcing us to learn about it in our own time outside class (time better served working on the stakeholder process).
It can be better structured.
I don't see a clear improvement in this class.

I'm unsure how to improve this course, but I think it was frustrating to some that a PhD student did a majority of the teaching, and was most knowledgable in the subject. It's okay, because she is VERY knowledgeable, but then the course started to revolve around her personal research, which again, was relevant, and she is very qualified, but I think if this class was taught by someone with experience in this area - like Ben, etc, it could be more valuable.

It would be great if the stakeholders could provide an outline of expectations, and what things he or she wants to get out of the working relationship with students early in the semester. It takes some time to get started with the work in the semester.

Need more direction from professor as well, just in terms of offering more content and instruction on some of our topics. We dove into a very complex issue (REDD) that I don't think any class at FES really prepares you for, so it was slow-going for the first couple of months, and we felt like we were grasping in the dark. Need to put more work beforehand into defining the deliverables from the client organizations and looking into their backgrounds a bit. Our project was very controversial and we even wondered whether it was ethical to support it or give it legitimacy with Yale's name as a collaborator.I think the mock negotiation should happen sooner, and we could use a more structured lecture and exercise on the UNFCCC process earlier in the semester. I was completely lost for the first several weeks, but after the mock negotiation, all the alphabet soup and terms really made sense.
helping communications with clients

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Angel is fantastic!
Both the instructor and TA were valuable resources and always accessible.
TA was fantastic, although I felt she was too busy to bother with questions and ask for help.
Very helpful
The help and quality of both instructor and TA was outstanding. Always available, always helpful and always going that extra mile to secure the best of experiences to the student.
Great.
Both were very responsive and helpful.
Angel and Gordon make a great team, and we proactive in supporting the stakeholder groups, and were always available out of class to help with our projects.
They were both very helpful to students in ensuring that we got as much out of the class as we invested in.

Gordon was incredibly supportive and helpful, although I think the topics might be outside of his field. Logistical and financial support was unparalleled in terms of getting us what we needed in New Haven, New York, and Durban. Angel was amazing, I don't know how managed to balance everything she is doing, but she always made time for us, really pushed us to stay on task, and really opened doors for us. She juggled so many difficulties and challenges for this course, in addition to working on her own stuff, yet always had a smile on her face and found ways to help us. One of the nicest and best TAs ever!

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: n/a
It helped me network with officials from external stakeholders.

This course deals with the dynamics in the international diplomacy and policy arenas, both great abilities that are essential to what I want to specialize in. This course fits perfectly into my program.
Overall skill based course, started a foundation for other future partnerships with like organizations, networking, real professionalism standard. Amazing experience thankfully to Yale.

My career objective is to work wit NGOS such as WRI among others on Forest and related climate issues. So to have gotten that experience of working with them was very fulfilling. I feel confident that I would do well in an organization such as this because of the opportunity I had through this course.

As a second year student, this course has helped me more than any other in giving me a window and contacts on potential job opportunities and projects in the future. I now have dozens of new contacts that I can at least share information with and check with if I'm looking for potential opportunities in the field. The class is client-driven, real-world, and yet gives you the safety net of Yale while you feel out the project. So it gives you such a useful practical experience, perhaps because of the difficulties you face, that these types of courses should be offered more widely.
yes

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To learn about a subject matter that I am not too familiar with and to work with real stakeholders
I was interested in taking project-based courses that involved working with clients so that my coursework would have real world applications.
To get opportunity to work with NGO's
I took this course because I felt it gave me a set of skills and opportunities that I needed to deepen my understanding in the subject. It proved to be so.

For the amazing skills and opportunities presented, to attend conferences, even though there wasn't enough funding for all of us to attend, some of us get to attend other conferences, UN events, network, meet people in our field, get connected for internships and job opportunities.
I wanted to learn about the global climate change policy system.
To develop skills needed to work with an environmental organization, which involves working in teams to solve an issue.
Wanted to work on a real-world project and travel to the COP-17 at Durban.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes

No. I expected to gain a more thorough and nuanced understanding of the global climate change negotiations and the issues and sticking points being debated, in a way that would improve my understanding of global environmental politics and build upon my previous experience with the global climate change negotiations while working for another international organization. I did not plan on attending Durban or the Rio+20 intersessional (although I did attend the latter), because I believe that attendance at these meetings is not very valuable but it is definitely valuable to learn about them and think about their role in the landscape of environmental institutions. Instead of learning about the climate change negotiations or building a good relationship with a prominent organization, I learned about the perils of managing groupwork. Definitely not what I wanted.
Yes, sort of.
Yes, I have to say that it exceeded my expectations. It was such a joy to take this course.
Yes
Yes and No.
YES
Yes!
Yes it did and more.
Absolutely. The project was more complicated than we initially imagined, but we got an excellent professional experience.
yes

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes
See answer to question 17
Yes. However, it would have been great if we were given opportunity to visit our stakeholder to know more about their work.

No, I got much more of what I expected to get. Sincerely all the effort and hours put in this class has opened many many doors of opportunities and the overall learning experience is one I truly cherish.
Yes
I was expecting the chance to travel to either durban or Rio, and was of course disappointed that was not an option after putting in so much hard work.
Yes and more!
This was a great class. I worked with a wonderful stakeholder, and really felt that I was doing something that actually mattered.
Yes I did.
Yes, and much more.
yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It really helped to bounce ideas off of my partners

Yes. Disadvantages: group members dont understand the issues, dont do the work to bring themselves up to speed, prioritize other work, turn in poor quality work, dont provide feedback or edits on documents, not responsive to email, show up late to meetings. No advantages. The whole process was three times more stressful to create a product of significantly lower quality than if I had done the whole project myself.
Group work helped us divide the responsibilities and work given by stakeholder.

I have to say that group work was intense. It required many many hours of works, many more than I initially intended to for this class. However all of them were used in the best learning experience. The kind of skills and tools learned in this class are really unique for anyone's experience.
na
Gained so much knowledge and respect from my peers!

This class is based on group work, and I had a good experience with my stakeholder and teammates. However, I can see that this would be a difficult course to get through if either of those working relationships were not functioning.

It's obviously more real world, but you really have to work to make sure work happens on schedule. If there's any hemming and hawing, important to simply start working on something that your teammates can then improve and comment upon. Good communication is key so that all members feel respected and accounted for; let people know what you are doing.
keeping up tight schedules and deadlines

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Be prepared to be proactive and creative.

The quality of experience one has in this course has everything to do with group work. Begin the group work immediately with making sure everyone is up to speed on the issues and create a sense of accountability.
Be very pro-active ! Reach out to your stakeholder and try to learn as much as you can from them.
Try to set a work plan with your stakeholder as soon as possible so you can profit the most of this experience.
You get out of this class what you put into it.
Don't expect to attend any conferences out of it, just try to get what you can out of it without that part.
Throw yourself into it.

This is a great course to take. It's refreshing to have a chance to work on real-world issues as opposed to writing papers that you will never look at again. Whether or not go you go to a conference, it is still a valuable class. The guest lecturer format makes every class different, and you get a working knowledge of a variety of topics that you may not be familiar with.
You get more out of it as much as you put in.

Do everything you can to go to the conference for the entire time (2 weeks); that means getting all your other class work out of the way as quickly as possible. The opportunities for networking, fun, travel, and presenting are unparalleled at the COPs, and you want to give them all your time.Define expectations and start work on the client project early in the semester! Even if you are struggling with the direction, just dive into it headfirst and create something; it will come together better that way. We agonized over the direction of the project for too long, and ended up having to leave a lot of stuff out of the policy memo anyway. Might as well do that earlier and have more time to refine the memo.
talk to professor first see if you can find the right client for you
